Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: From 1996 to 2010, south-eastern Australia experienced prolonged dry conditions with rainfall persistently well below average, particularly during the cooler months from April to October. The most acute period of the so-called 'Millennium drought' was between 2001 and 2009. The drought finished with the arrival of wet La Niña conditions during 2010 and 2011, with particularly heavy summer rainfall.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: The drought in 1982–83 is regarded as the worst of the twentieth century for short-term rainfall deficiencies of up to one year and their over-all impact. There were severe dust storms in north-western Victoria and severe bushfires in south-east Australia in February 1983 with 75 people killed.

There were severe dust storms in north-western Victoria and severe bushfires in south-east Australia in February 1983 with 75 people killed.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: The drought in 1982–83 is regarded as the worst of the twentieth century for short-term rainfall deficiencies of up to one year and their over-all impact. There were severe dust storms in north-western Victoria and severe bushfires in south-east Australia in February 1983 with 75 people killed.

Time_with_Annotation: From 1996 to 2010, south-eastern Australia experienced prolonged dry conditions with rainfall persistently well below average, particularly during the cooler months from April to October. The most acute period of the so-called 'Millennium drought' was between 2001 and 2009. The drought finished with the arrival of wet La Niña conditions during 2010 and 2011, with particularly heavy summer rainfall.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Insured_Da.Insured_Damage_Assessment_with_annotatio: Around 20 cotton communities and 10,000 people directly employed by the cotton industry were impacted by the drought. The main areas affected were in New South Wales: Menindee, where the area under production was reduced by 100%, Bourke, area reduced by 99%, Walgett by 95%, the Macquarie River by 74% and Gwydir River by 60%. In Queensland, the worst-affected areas were Biloela, which reduced the area under production by 100%, Dirranbandi, by 91%, Central Highlands by 82% and Darling Downs by 78%.

Location_with_Annotation.Murray-Darling Basin: South-east Australia experienced its second driest year on record in 2006, particularly affecting the major agricultural region of the Murray–Darling basin.
Location_with_Annotation.eastern Australia: According to the Bureau of Meteorology, much of eastern Australia experienced a dry 2001.
Location_with_Annotation.south-eastern Australia: From 1996 to 2010, south-eastern Australia experienced prolonged dry conditions with rainfall persistently well below average, particularly during the cooler months from April to October.
Location_with_Annotation.New South Wales: 2002 was one of Australia's driest and warmest years on record, with 'remarkably widespread' dry conditions, particularly in the eastern half of the country, which was again affected by El Niño conditions.
Location_with_Annotation.Victoria: 2007 saw record temperatures across the south of Australia, and only patchy rain; promising early year rains contrasted with a very dry July–October period, meaning that drought conditions persisted across much of the south-east.
Location_with_Annotation.Tasmania: 2017 was a drier than average year for much of inland Queensland, most of New South Wales, eastern and central Victoria, and all of Tasmania.
Location_with_Annotation.Queensland: Dry conditions again began to develop and be sustained in mid-2013 through much of western Queensland.
Location_with_Annotation.Menindee: The main areas affected were in New South Wales: Menindee, where the area under production was reduced by 100%.
Location_with_Annotation.Bourke: The main areas affected were in New South Wales: Bourke, area reduced by 99%.
Location_with_Annotation.Walgett: The main areas affected were in New South Wales: Walgett by 95%.
Location_with_Annotation.Macquarie River: The main areas affected were in New South Wales: the Macquarie River by 74%.
Location_with_Annotation.Gwydir River: The main areas affected were in New South Wales: Gwydir River by 60%.
Location_with_Annotation.Biloela: In Queensland, the worst-affected areas were Biloela, which reduced the area under production by 100%.
Location_with_Annotation.Dirranbandi: In Queensland, the worst-affected areas were Dirranbandi, by 91%.
Location_with_Annotation.Central Highlands: In Queensland, the worst-affected areas were Central Highlands by 82%.
Location_with_Annotation.Darling Downs: In Queensland, the worst-affected areas were Darling Downs by 78%.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Economic_D.Economic_Damage_Assessment_with_annotati: Around 20 cotton communities and 10,000 people directly employed by the cotton industry were impacted by the drought. The main areas affected were in New South Wales: Menindee, where the area under production was reduced by 100%, Bourke, area reduced by 99%, Walgett by 95%, the Macquarie River by 74% and Gwydir River by 60%. In Queensland, the worst-affected areas were Biloela, which reduced the area under production by 100%, Dirranbandi, by 91%, Central Highlands by 82% and Darling Downs by 78%. Bourke has only had adequate water for one cotton crop in the last five years.

Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Drought: From 1996 to 2010, south-eastern Australia experienced prolonged dry conditions with rainfall persistently well below average, particularly during the cooler months from April to October. The most acute period of the so-called 'Millennium drought' was between 2001 and 2009.
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Heatwave: The effects of the drought were exacerbated by Australia's (then) second hottest year on record in 2009, with record-breaking heatwaves in January, February and the second half of the year.
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Wildfire: There were severe dust storms in north-western Victoria and severe bushfires in south-east Australia in February 1983 with 75 people killed.
Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Flood: Australia's weather pattern transitioned rapidly to a wet La Niña pattern during autumn, resulting in record-breaking rains in the Murray-Darling Basin and well above average rainfall across the south-east. For many locations this was the first year of above-average rainfall since 1996. The rainfall dramatically increased surface water storage and soil moisture, effectively ending the drought in the south-east.

The main areas affected were in New South Wales: Menindee, where the area under production was reduced by 100%, Bourke, area reduced by 99%, Walgett by 95%, the Macquarie River by 74% and Gwydir River by 60%. In Queensland, the worst-affected areas were Biloela, which reduced the area under production by 100%, Dirranbandi, by 91%, Central Highlands by 82% and Darling Downs by 78%.
